title: Two key triggers and their mechanisms of the spring rainy season onset over southern China
abstract:
•The RSO over southern China is collectively triggered by synoptic-scale disturbances and quasi-biweekly oscillation. •Synoptic disturbances are baroclinic, drive post-onset rainfall surge, while QBWO is quasi-barotropic, maintains rainfall. •Both systems trigger the RSO by stronger moisture transport and ascent via upward-increasing vorticity and warm advection. 
 Based on daily precipitation data from the China Meteorological Administration and reanalysis data from the Japan Meteorological Agency during 1979–2023, this study finds that the synoptic-scale disturbances and the quasi-biweekly oscillation (QBWO) have crucial influence on the spring rainy season onset (RSO) over southern China. Pronounced changes in precipitation are identified before and after the RSO dates on both synoptic and quasi-biweekly timescales, associated with distinct atmospheric circulations. On the synoptic timescale, the RSO is typically preceded by the development of a lower-tropospheric cyclone and a mid-tropospheric baroclinic trough to the west of southern China, enhancing moisture transport from the South China Sea. Meanwhile, on the quasi-biweekly timescale, the key circulation features consist of a broad quasi-barotropic cyclone encircling the Tibetan Plateau and a corresponding anticyclone over the Bay of Bengal in the lower and middle troposphere, jointly facilitating moisture advection from the Arabian Sea. These systems amplify geostrophic relative vorticity anomalies over East Asia and sharpen the zonal gradient of relative vorticity, thereby contributing to upward motion through dynamic processes. From a thermodynamic perspective, the intensification of the cyclone to the west of southern China strengthens southerly winds, which promotes warm air advection and further reinforces vertical ascent. The synergy between these dynamic and thermodynamic processes sustain ascending motion, thereby facilitating the RSO in conjunction with enhanced low-level moisture transport. Clarifying the circulation characteristics triggering the RSO will aid in better predicting the start of the local rainy season in both weather forecasts and extended-range outlooks, then guiding spring farming activities.

title: Extreme rainfall south of the Yangtze River in China during June 2024: Observational diagnosis and dynamical downscaling prediction
abstract:
•Tropical sea surface temperatures and the boreal summer intraseasonal oscillation jointly forced this extreme rainfall event and associated circulation. •The CWRF regional model outperforms its nested global model in predicting rainfall, attributed to its better simulation of warmer Bay of Bengal SSTs and their relationships with precipitation. •U-Net experiments reveal that the CWRF's predictive skill for this precipitation originated primarily from its superior representation of lower-tropospheric meridional wind. 
 Extreme precipitation events are highly destructive, but their accurate prediction poses a significant challenge because the physical mechanisms underlying each event are uniquely complex. In June 2024, extreme heavy rainfall struck regions south of the Yangtze River (SYR) in China, marking the highest precipitation anomaly of the corresponding period near Dongting Lake since 1961. This led to the year's first flood of Dongting Lake and a levee breach in Huarong County, causing substantial damage to agricultural fields, infrastructure facilities, and residential areas. Regarding external sea surface temperature (SST) forcing, the elevated SSTs in the tropical North Atlantic and Indian Ocean combined with cold SSTs in the eastern equatorial Pacific contributed to this extreme rainfall, with the Indian Ocean playing a dominant role. In terms of internal atmospheric variability, the boreal summer intraseasonal oscillation (BSISO) subsequently triggered subseasonal precipitation anomalies and further intensified precipitation during late June 2024. A global climate model (BCC_CPSv3) initialized in May produced a northward deviation in the heavy rainfall belt in June 2024. Through dynamical downscaling, the regional climate model (CWRF) improved the spatial distribution of the precipitation prediction. This improvement was primarily attributed to the more realistic representation of warmer SSTs in the Bay of Bengal and the South China Sea, and their relationships with precipitation in the regional model. A U-Net model based on the nonlinear relationship between circulation and precipitation was employed to pinpoint the circulation sources of prediction skill and error in the regional model. The experimental results revealed that the prediction skill of CWRF for precipitation in the SYR region during June 2024 stemmed mainly from its accurate representation of lower-tropospheric meridional wind. However, its simulation of lower-tropospheric humidity remains inadequate and requires further improvement.

authors: Haolong Zhang;Zheng Zhang;Wenhui Lin;Guohui Lin;Cheng Luo;Ting Fang;Nemin Luo;Minggang Cai;Lei Wang;Bin Yan;Yan Lin
title: Disentangling seasonal dynamics and transboundary transport of PAHs in a coastal monsoon city
abstract:
•Seasonal shift observed between gas- and particle-phase PAHs in coastal China. •Coal and gasoline emissions dominated wintertime PAH toxicity. •66 % of PAHs traced to northern China and Southeast Asia via SRA and PSCF. •XGBoost-SHAP revealed ring-dependent PAH responses to environmental driver. 
 Atmospheric polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) pose serious environmental and health risks due to their toxicity, persistence, and long-range transport potential. Yet, their seasonal dynamics, regional sources, and nonlinear regulatory mechanisms remain unclear in subtropical coastal regions influenced by monsoonal circulation. We monitored 23 parent and 8 derivative PAHs year-round in Xiamen, China, and applied PMF, trajectory analysis, and XGBoost to investigate their sources and nonlinear environmental drivers. The results revealed clear seasonal variation: particulate-phase PAHs peaked in winter (11.37 ng/m3) and declined in summer (0.13 ng/m3), while gaseous compounds showed the opposite trend. The gas-particle partition coefficients (log Kₚ) showed a strong positive correlation with the octanol-air partition coefficients (log Kₒₐ), while displaying a marked negative correlation with ambient temperature, reflecting the dual influence of compound traits and environmental conditions on phase behavior. PMF identified six major source factors, among which coal combustion and gasoline vehicle emissions were the leading contributors to wintertime toxicity, accounting for 56.73 % of the toxic equivalent (∑TEQ). Potential Source Contribution Function (PSCF) and Source Region Attribution (SRA) showed that the PAH pollution in Xiamen mainly comes from local source (34 %), northern and northeastern China (46 %) and Southeast Asia and south China Sea (20 %). SHAP-based interpretation of the XGBoost model demonstrated that low-ring PAHs were more sensitive to local meteorological conditions, while high-ring PAHs exhibited stronger association with air mass origins and particle-phase accumulation. These findings reveal seasonal PAH patterns in coastal air and underscore the importance of distinguishing local from transboundary sources.
